title: 110_s961
content: The Act titled "Belated Thank You to the Merchant Mariners of World War II Act of 2007" amends Chapter 112 of title 46, United States Code to provide monthly benefits for World War II Merchant Mariners and survivors. This includes a new subchapter for burial and cemetery benefits for veterans and a new subchapter for monthly benefits. The Act provides a monthly benefit of $1,000 to individuals with a certificate of honorable service and their surviving spouses. Surviving spouses must have been married to the individual for at least one year to be eligible. Retroactive eligibility for benefits is also included. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will provide retroactive monthly benefits to individuals and surviving spouses who were issued certificates of honorable service under the Belated Thank You to the Merchant Mariners of World War II Act of 2007. The Belated Thank You to the Merchant Mariners of World War II Act of 2007 exempts payments of benefits from taxation. Qualified service for this act includes individuals who served in the United States merchant marine between December 7, 1941, and December 31, 1946. The Belated Thank You to the Merchant Mariners of World War II Act of 2007 exempts benefits from taxation for individuals who served in the US merchant marine between December 7, 1941, and December 31, 1946. To qualify, individuals must have served on vessels in inland waters, the Great Lakes, or other US lakes, bays, and harbors under contract to the US government and serving the Armed Forces. They must also have been licensed or documented for service by an authorized US officer or employee. Applicants must submit an application for a certificate of honorable service to the Secretary of Transportation. The Belated Thank You to the Merchant Mariners of World War II Act of 2007 exempts benefits from taxation for individuals who served in the US merchant marine between December 7, 1941, and December 31, 1946. To qualify, individuals must have served on vessels in inland waters, the Great Lakes, or other US lakes, bays, and harbors under contract to the US government and serving the Armed Forces. They must also have been licensed or documented for service by an authorized US officer or employee. Applicants must submit an application for a certificate of honorable service to the Secretary of Transportation or the Secretary of Defense if they were a member of the Army Transport Service or the Naval Transport Service. The Secretary who receives the application shall issue the certificate if the individual engaged in qualified service and meets the specified standards within one year of receiving the application. The Secretary will apply standards for honorable discharge under the GI Bill Improvement Act of 1977 to applications for certificates of honorable service. Surviving spouses of individuals who engaged in qualifying service can also apply for a certificate to receive benefits. The term "surviving spouse" is defined in this subchapter. The term "veteran" in this subchapter refers to an individual who performed qualified service. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Amendments are made to section 11201 of title 46, United States Code. The curr_chunk introduces a new subchapter on monthly benefits for veterans, including provisions for a monthly benefit, qualified service, certificate of honorable service, definition of surviving spouse, and authorization of appropriations.
